text: [Music]
so we are software platform that works
in the a/v space and we focus on fully
autonomous fleets and working on the
heart if structure problems of getting
those vehicles to scale dealing with the
applications and the data massive
amounts of data that these vehicles
produce each autonomous vehicle will
generate about four to five terabytes of
data per hour per vehicle so if you do
like a quick add up of that a fleet of
only 2000 cars generates more data per
day than Facebook and a place like
Manhattan probably needs 10 or 20,000 of
these things to fully service all the
people so you can see that just getting
that data moving it from the vehicles to
where it needs to go is a massive
infrastructure challenge unlike anything
we've seen and it runs in the opposite
direction of the way every network has
been designed it's mostly designed to go
from the center to the edge this is from
an edge to the center so it's brand new
technology brand new challenges I think
it's dawned on people that data is
valuable and I think there's a lot of
people that have worked with data in
other contexts that now see vehicles and
particularly autonomous vehicles as a
huge opportunity I think the challenge
that they have is that they're coming at
this from sort of a iot-cloud centric
view and you really have to understand
what's going on in the car you have to
understand how the data is collected how
its prioritized how it interacts with
the applications on the vehicle to
understand what to do with it and so
companies like ours we've been doing
this for about nine years we've gotten
quite good at understanding the car and
that gives us an unfair advantage in
building these data systems but that
said there are large companies
particularly cloud centric companies
that are starting to see this and we can
we can meet in the middle we can help
enable their business models and drive
more value into their platforms and they
can make what we're doing a lot more
efficient and advantageous for our
shared customers which are generally the
people operating these fleets of cars
yeah so I think what has changed over
the past ten years is you don't set up
your own infrastructure to go and build
something and even if it's going to be
huge
you start with with partners in space
and AWS has been a great partner and not
only that has been a willing partner to
support not just my startup but other
startups in the space getting on that
platform that's really important I think
it makes it easy to work with them in
the beginning and as our business has
grown they've continued to reach out to
us to ask how can we better be better
what can we do to more collaborate
that's really positive and so I think
this is a competitive space and there
are a lot of choices and so going the
extra mile particularly the startups is
welcome from the AWS side and we
appreciate it
